channel.title: WPR Reports
channel.description: "WPR Reports" features in-depth investigations from Wisconsin Public Radio. The current season, "Uprooted," retraces the experiences of the nearly 15,000 Cuban refugees who were sent to Wisconsin's Fort McCoy after the Mariel Boatlift in 1980 and examines the lives of those who have made Wisconsin home. It debuts in October 2022.
channel.itunes:summary: "WPR Reports" features in-depth investigations from Wisconsin Public Radio. The current season, "Uprooted," retraces the experiences of the nearly 15,000 Cuban refugees who were sent to Wisconsin's Fort McCoy after the Mariel Boatlift in 1980 and examines the lives of those who have made Wisconsin home. It debuts in October 2022.
channel.itunes:keywords: Wisconsin Public Radio, Wisconsin, redistricting, electoral maps, gerrymandering, partisan, Cuba, Cuban, Fort McCoy, Mariel Boatlift, refugee, evacuee, La Crosse, exile, Wisconsin Life, train, high-speed rail, Scott Walker, Jim Doyle, Tommy Thompson
channel.itunes:author: Wisconsin Public Radio

item.title: Uprooted, Ep. 8: Cuba is Calling
item.description: The Cuban exiles who arrived in Wisconsin in 1980 as part of the Mariel Boatlift have become family to one another. They are Wisconsinites. But their hearts remain in Cuba, and they want to visit their homeland one more time - if they can find a way.
item.author: web-team@wpr.org (Wisconsin Public Radio)
item.category: Culture, History, North American History, Justice, Social Issues, Immigration, Latino, Race
item.itunes:summary: The Cuban exiles who arrived in Wisconsin in 1980 as part of the Mariel Boatlift have become family to one another. They are Wisconsinites. But their hearts remain in Cuba, and they want to visit their homeland one more time - if they can find a way.
item.itunes:keywords: Culture, History, North American History, Justice, Social Issues, Immigration, Latino, Race
item.itunes:author: Wisconsin Public Radio
item.itunes:title: Uprooted: Cuba is Calling
item.media:title: Uprooted, Ep. 8: Cuba is Calling
item.media:description: The Cuban exiles who arrived in Wisconsin in 1980 as part of the Mariel Boatlift have become family to one another. They are Wisconsinites. But their hearts remain in Cuba, and they want to visit their homeland one more time - if they can find a way.
item.media:credit: Cuban refugees play music in Pozo and Rodriguez's living room

item.title: Uprooted, Ep. 7: Crime and Adversity
item.description: Some Mariel refugees made questionable decisions while adjusting to life in the Midwest in the 1980s. They've all faced discrimination. And all of them have tried to move forward as their pasts continue to haunt them.
item.author: web-team@wpr.org (Wisconsin Public Radio)
item.category: Culture, History, North American History, Justice, Social Issues, Immigration, Latino, Race

item.title: Uprooted, Ep. 6: Becoming a Wisconsinite
item.description: The Cubans who immigrated to the United States during the Mariel Boatlift have left Fort McCoy. Some found homes in Wisconsin and got jobs. Some started families. But first, they had to find sponsors.
item.author: web-team@wpr.org (Wisconsin Public Radio)
item.category: Culture, History, North American History, Justice, Social Issues, Immigration, Latino, Race

item.media:description: The Cubans who immigrated to the United States during the Mariel Boatlift have left Fort McCoy. Some found homes in Wisconsin and got jobs. Some started families. But first, they had to find sponsors.

item.title: Uprooted, Ep. 5: A New Home at Fort McCoy
item.description: Fort McCoy was one of four U.S. military installations that housed Cuban refugees after the Mariel Boatlift in 1980. Almost 15,000 Cubans lived there that summer and fall while waiting to connect with family members or find sponsors.
item.author: web-team@wpr.org (Wisconsin Public Radio)
item.category: Culture, History, North American History, Justice, Social Issues, Immigration, Latino, Race

item.media:credit: Cuban refugees at Fort McCoy in 1980 play cards and gamble for cigarettes

item.title: Uprooted, Ep. 4: The Mariel Boatlift
item.description: People who left Cuba to come to the United States as part of the Mariel Boatlift in 1980 share their experiences of traveling across the sea and their first memories stepping ashore in Florida.
item.author: web-team@wpr.org (Wisconsin Public Radio)

item.media:description: People who left Cuba to come to the United States as part of the Mariel Boatlift in 1980 share their experiences of traveling across the sea and their first memories stepping ashore in Florida.

item.title: Uprooted, Ep. 3: Failed Dreams and Embassy Breaks
item.description: The Cuban revolution promised people a better life: free health care, schools and subsidized housing for everyone. But this came at a cost - and some weren't willing to pay the price. So they began leaving the country in the 1960s, and it all came to a head in 1980.
item.author: web-team@wpr.org (Wisconsin Public Radio)
item.category: Culture, History, North American History, Justice, Social Issues, Immigration, Latino, Race

item.title: Uprooted, Ep. 2: Youth Lost to a Revolution
item.description: When Fidel Castro took control of Cuba in 1959, some feared the shift to communism and left almost right away. Decades later, the changes brought on by the revolution would also lead to almost 15,000 Cuban refugees coming to Wisconsin as part of the Mariel Boatlift of 1980.
item.author: web-team@wpr.org (Wisconsin Public Radio)
item.category: Culture, History, North American History, Justice, Social Issues, Immigration, Latino, Race

item.title: Uprooted, Ep. 1: From Cuba to Oktoberfest
item.description: Enrique More has roots in La Crosse. He's been a part of the city's music scene for decades, most notably playing with Mr. Blink. Wisconsin is his home. But it didn't feel much like home when he first got here, when he was one of a handful of Cubans to settle in La Crosse after arriving in 1980 as part of the Mariel Boatlift.
item.author: web-team@wpr.org (Wisconsin Public Radio)

item.title: Introducing: Uprooted
item.description: In 1980, nearly 15,000 Cuban refugees were sent to Fort McCoy in Wisconsin. They left their homes as part of the Mariel boatlift mass exodus. In this podcast, meet the Cubans who stayed in Wisconsin and find out what their lives have been like as they live in legal limbo.
item.author: web-team@wpr.org (Wisconsin Public Radio)
item.category: Culture, History, American History, Cultural History, South American History, Politics, Social Issues, Immigration, Poverty, Race
item.itunes:summary: In 1980, nearly 15,000 Cuban refugees were sent to Fort McCoy in Wisconsin. They left their homes as part of the Mariel boatlift mass exodus. In this podcast, meet the Cubans who stayed in Wisconsin and find out what their lives have been like as they live in legal limbo.
item.itunes:keywords: Culture, History, American History, Cultural History, South American History, Politics, Social Issues, Immigration, Poverty, Race

item.title: Mapped Out, Ep. 8: The Final Map
item.description: When people look back at Wisconsin's redistricting cycle of 2021, they might wonder how the Republican-led Legislature came out on top again, despite repeated and significant setbacks.
item.author: web-team@wpr.org (Wisconsin Public Radio)
item.itunes:summary: When people look back at Wisconsin's redistricting cycle of 2021, they might wonder how the Republican-led Legislature came out on top again, despite repeated and significant setbacks.
item.itunes:keywords: Redistricting, electoral, electoral maps, gerrymandering, Wisconsin, politics, Republicans, Democrats, party, partisan, control, U.S. Census, representatives, Legislature, Congress
item.itunes:author: Wisconsin Public Radio
item.itunes:title: Mapped Out: The Final Map
item.media:title: Mapped Out, Ep. 8: The Final Map
item.media:description: When people look back at Wisconsin's redistricting cycle of 2021, they might wonder how the Republican-led Legislature came out on top again, despite repeated and significant setbacks.

item.title: Mapped Out, Ep. 7: Least Changes
item.description: The new redistricting maps proposed by Republican leaders in the state Legislature are based on the old maps approved in 2011. And while it may have been obscured by the partisan bickering that greeted the proposal, an important question emerges: Can the map that helped Republicans cement their majorities for the past decade be reused for the next 10 years?
item.author: web-team@wpr.org (Wisconsin Public Radio)
item.itunes:summary: The new redistricting maps proposed by Republican leaders in the state Legislature are based on the old maps approved in 2011. And while it may have been obscured by the partisan bickering that greeted the proposal, an important question emerges: Can the map that helped Republicans cement their majorities for the past decade be reused for the next 10 years?
item.itunes:keywords: Redistricting, electoral, electoral maps, gerrymandering, Wisconsin, politics, Republicans, Democrats, party, partisan, control, U.S. Census, representatives, Legislature, Congress
item.itunes:author: Wisconsin Public Radio
item.itunes:title: Mapped Out: Least Changes
item.media:title: Mapped Out, Ep. 7: Least Changes
item.media:description: The new redistricting maps proposed by Republican leaders in the state Legislature are based on the old maps approved in 2011. And while it may have been obscured by the partisan bickering that greeted the proposal, an important question emerges: Can the map that helped Republicans cement their majorities for the past decade be reused for the next 10 years?

item.title: Mapped Out, Ep. 6: How It Might Go
item.description: In Wisconsin, it's the job of the Legislature and the governor to handle redistricting every decade, and pretty much no one thinks they're actually going to do it this time around. With split control of state government, things are likely headed to court, but which court and when are still open questions.
item.author: web-team@wpr.org (Wisconsin Public Radio)
item.itunes:summary: In Wisconsin, it's the job of the Legislature and the governor to handle redistricting every decade, and pretty much no one thinks they're actually going to do it this time around. With split control of state government, things are likely headed to court, but which court and when are still open questions.
item.itunes:keywords: Redistricting, electoral, electoral maps, gerrymandering, Wisconsin, politics, Republicans, Democrats, party, partisan, control, U.S. Census, representatives, Legislature, Congress
item.itunes:author: Wisconsin Public Radio
item.itunes:title: Mapped Out: How It Might Go
item.media:title: Mapped Out, Ep. 6: How It Might Go
item.media:description: In Wisconsin, it's the job of the Legislature and the governor to handle redistricting every decade, and pretty much no one thinks they're actually going to do it this time around. With split control of state government, things are likely headed to court, but which court and when are still open questions.

item.title: Mapped Out, Ep. 5: Locked In
item.description: It's one thing to talk about the power of political redistricting in the abstract, but what does it look like in practice? Over the last decade, Wisconsin's map has let Republicans pass landmark conservative policies, keep a tight grip on the state budget, reshape government agencies and mothball issues despite public support.
item.author: web-team@wpr.org (Wisconsin Public Radio)
item.itunes:summary: It's one thing to talk about the power of political redistricting in the abstract, but what does it look like in practice? Over the last decade, Wisconsin's map has let Republicans pass landmark conservative policies, keep a tight grip on the state budget, reshape government agencies and mothball issues despite public support.
item.itunes:keywords: Redistricting, electoral, electoral maps, gerrymandering, Wisconsin, politics, Republicans, Democrats, party, partisan, control, U.S. Census, representatives, Legislature, Congress
item.itunes:author: Wisconsin Public Radio
item.itunes:title: Mapped Out: Locked In
item.media:title: Mapped Out, Ep. 5:Locked In
item.media:description: It's one thing to talk about the power of political redistricting in the abstract, but what does it look like in practice? Over the last decade, Wisconsin's map has let Republicans pass landmark conservative policies, keep a tight grip on the state budget, reshape government agencies and mothball issues despite public support.

item.title: Mapped Out, Ep. 4: Courting Anthony Kennedy
item.description: The legislative maps that Wisconsin Republicans drew a decade ago are still standing. But an effort that started in a Milwaukee teahouse and snowballed all the way to the U.S. Supreme Court very well could have changed the whole game of redistricting — in Wisconsin and nationwide.
item.author: web-team@wpr.org (Wisconsin Public Radio)
item.itunes:summary: The legislative maps that Wisconsin Republicans drew a decade ago are still standing. But an effort that started in a Milwaukee teahouse and snowballed all the way to the U.S. Supreme Court very well could have changed the whole game of redistricting — in Wisconsin and nationwide.
item.itunes:keywords: Redistricting, electoral, electoral maps, gerrymandering, Wisconsin, politics, Republicans, Democrats, party, partisan, control, U.S. Census, representatives, Legislature, Congress
item.itunes:author: Wisconsin Public Radio
item.itunes:title: Mapped Out: Courting Anthony Kennedy
item.media:title: Mapped Out, Ep. 4: Courting Anthony Kennedy
item.media:description: The legislative maps that Wisconsin Republicans drew a decade ago are still standing. But an effort that started in a Milwaukee teahouse and snowballed all the way to the U.S. Supreme Court very well could have changed the whole game of redistricting — in Wisconsin and nationwide.

item.title: Mapped Out, Ep. 3: The Mousetrap
item.description: Some districts split towns apart. Others packed all the votes in a city together, or stretched to join urban with suburban. But taken together, Republicans' 2011 legislative maps did one thing: changed the game in Wisconsin politics.
item.author: web-team@wpr.org (Wisconsin Public Radio)
item.itunes:summary: Some districts split towns apart. Others packed all the votes in a city together, or stretched to join urban with suburban. But taken together, Republicans' 2011 legislative maps did one thing: changed the game in Wisconsin politics.
item.itunes:keywords: Redistricting, electoral, electoral maps, gerrymandering, Wisconsin, politics, Republicans, Democrats, party, partisan, control, U.S. Census, representatives, Legislature, Congress
item.itunes:author: Wisconsin Public Radio
item.itunes:title: Mapped Out: The Mousetrap
item.media:title: Mapped Out, Ep. 3: The Mousetrap
item.media:description: Some districts split towns apart. Others packed all the votes in a city together, or stretched to join urban with suburban. But taken together, Republicans' 2011 legislative maps did one thing: changed the game in Wisconsin politics.

item.title: Mapped Out, Ep. 2: Chaos and Quiet
item.description: 2011 was a frenzied, historic year in Wisconsin politics, with massive protests over GOP legislation gutting the state's public employee unions. But at the same time, quietly, behind closed doors, Republicans were drawing maps that would cement their power for a decade.
item.author: web-team@wpr.org (Wisconsin Public Radio)
item.itunes:summary: 2011 was a frenzied, historic year in Wisconsin politics, with massive protests over GOP legislation gutting the state's public employee unions. But at the same time, quietly, behind closed doors, Republicans were drawing maps that would cement their power for a decade.

item.itunes:title: Mapped Out: Chaos and Quiet

item.media:description: 2011 was a frenzied, historic year in Wisconsin politics, with massive protests over GOP legislation gutting the state's public employee unions. But at the same time, quietly, behind closed doors, Republicans were drawing maps that would cement their power for a decade.

item.title: Mapped Out, Ep. 1: An Unseen Force
item.description: Wisconsin is the quintessential purple state, and yet the Legislature is very red. Why? It's partly because of redistricting, the process of drawing district lines every decade. It's not something most people learn about in civics class, but the way those maps are drawn and who draws them can have an enormous impact on who wields political power.
item.author: web-team@wpr.org (Wisconsin Public Radio)

item.title: Mapped Out: Trailer
item.description: In 2011, Wisconsin's legislative redistricting process included secret meetings, deleted documents and a case that went all the way to the U.S. Supreme Court. "Mapped Out" is an investigative series debuting in September that will give the low-down on the state's redistricting past and get ready for redistricting present.

item.title: Derailed: Bonus Episode
item.description: Because the story of "Derailed" happened over the course of decades, there's a lot there, and a lot we didn't get to. Some of it, like Gov. Jim Doyle's role in ending the train, is still discussed today. Other stuff, like the 2016 Olympics connection, seems to have been lost to history. Here are some of the questions we didn't get to in "Derailed."
item.author: web-team@wpr.org (Wisconsin Public Radio)
item.media:credit: collage of Jim Doyle, Chicago Olympics bid, Amtrak train
item.itunes:title: Derailed: Bonus Episode
item.itunes:summary: Because the story of "Derailed" happened over the course of decades, there's a lot there, and a lot we didn't get to. Some of it, like Gov. Jim Doyle's role in ending the train, is still discussed today. Other stuff, like the 2016 Olympics connection, seems to have been lost to history. Here are some of the questions we didn't get to in "Derailed."

item.title: Derailed, Ep. 6: Times Change
item.description: When former Gov. Tommy Thompson decided to return to politics in 2012, he was walking into a Wisconsin that was as divided as ever. The game had changed, and Thompson had to play by a new set of rules. That meant a new take on some of his old positions, including the train.
item.author: web-team@wpr.org (Wisconsin Public Radio)
item.itunes:title: Derailed: Times Change
item.itunes:summary: When former Gov. Tommy Thompson decided to return to politics in 2012, he was walking into a Wisconsin that was as divided as ever. The game had changed, and Thompson had to play by a new set of rules. That meant a new take on some of his old positions, including the train.

item.title: Derailed, Ep. 5: Going Nowhere
item.description: Before Gov. Scott Walker canceled the high-speed rail line that would have connected Madison to Milwaukee in 2010, Wisconsin bought two trains from a Spanish company named Talgo. The story of these trains is messy. And in a way, they're the physical reminder of the debate Wisconsin had almost a decade ago.
item.author: web-team@wpr.org (Wisconsin Public Radio)
item.media:credit: Wisconsin's Talgo trains sit at an Amtrak facility in Indiana
item.itunes:title: Derailed: Going Nowhere
item.itunes:summary: Before Gov. Scott Walker canceled the high-speed rail line that would have connected Madison to Milwaukee in 2010, Wisconsin bought two trains from a Spanish company named Talgo. The story of these trains is messy. And in a way, they're the physical reminder of the debate Wisconsin had almost a decade ago.

item.title: Derailed, Ep. 4: The Fast Train
item.description: When Wisconsin rejected $810 million in federal stimulus money for high-speed rail, the money was redistributed to other states. California got the largest chunk to go toward a rail line connecting San Francisco and Los Angeles, a project that is still ongoing.
item.author: web-team@wpr.org (Wisconsin Public Radio)
item.media:credit: A map showing the proposed initial construction of California's bullet train
item.itunes:title: Derailed: The Fast Train
item.itunes:summary: When Wisconsin rejected $810 million in federal stimulus money for high-speed rail, the money was redistributed to other states. California got the largest chunk to go toward a rail line connecting San Francisco and Los Angeles, a project that is still ongoing.

item.title: Derailed, Ep. 3: Boondoggle
item.description: In 2010, Democrats controlled everything, from the White House, to Congress, to the governor's office to the Wisconsin state Legislature. Republicans were pushing back, and the Tea Party was in full swing. But something was changing in American politics and in Wisconsin — and Scott Walker used the high-speed rail plan to seize the moment.
item.author: web-team@wpr.org (Wisconsin Public Radio)
item.media:credit: Wisconsin Republican gubernatorial candidate Scott Walker
item.itunes:title: Derailed: Boondoggle
item.itunes:summary: In 2010, Democrats controlled everything, from the White House, to Congress, to the governor's office to the Wisconsin state Legislature. Republicans were pushing back, and the Tea Party was in full swing. But something was changing in American politics and in Wisconsin — and Scott Walker used the high-speed rail plan to seize the moment.

item.title: Derailed, Ep. 2: Every Single Dime
item.description: Almost a decade after it was first unveiled, the Great Recession and President Barack Obama's federal stimulus bill gave Wisconsin's plan for a high-speed rail line new life.
item.author: web-team@wpr.org (Wisconsin Public Radio)
item.media:credit: President Barack Obama signs the American Recovery and Reinvestment Act
item.itunes:title: Derailed: Every Single Dime
item.itunes:summary: Almost a decade after it was first unveiled, the Great Recession and President Barack Obama's federal stimulus bill gave Wisconsin's plan for a high-speed rail line new life.

item.title: Derailed, Ep. 1: Tommy's Train
item.description: Even if you remember that it was Gov. Scott Walker who wanted to kill the high-speed rail line between Madison and Milwaukee, there's a chance you don't remember who started it. It wasn't Walker's Democratic opponent in 2010, Milwaukee Mayor Tom Barrett. Or the governor before Walker, Democrat Jim Doyle. Instead it was Wisconsin's longest-serving governor — a Republican governor — Gov. Tommy Thompson.
item.author: web-team@wpr.org (Wisconsin Public Radio)
item.media:credit: Gov. Tommy Thompson smiles during an interview
item.itunes:title: Derailed: Tommy's Train
item.itunes:summary: Even if you remember that it was Gov. Scott Walker who wanted to kill the high-speed rail line between Madison and Milwaukee, there's a chance you don't remember who started it. It wasn't Walker's Democratic opponent in 2010, Milwaukee Mayor Tom Barrett. Or the governor before Walker, Democrat Jim Doyle. Instead it was Wisconsin's longest-serving governor — a Republican governor — Gov. Tommy Thompson.

item.title: Derailed: Trailer
item.description: In 2010, Wisconsin got a federal grant to build a high-speed rail line between Madison and Milwaukee. Derailed is the story of how the rail project came together, how it fell apart and how Wisconsin changed along the way.
item.author: web-team@wpr.org (Wisconsin Public Radio)
item.itunes:title: Derailed: Trailer
item.itunes:summary: In 2010, Wisconsin got a federal grant to build a high-speed rail line between Madison and Milwaukee. Derailed is the story of how the rail project came together, how it fell apart and how Wisconsin changed along the way.
